thread.title: Why Did Gasoline Prices Fall by More Than 8% Last Week?
thread.title_full: Why Did Gasoline Prices Fall by More Than 8% Last Week?

title: Why Did Gasoline Prices Fall by More Than 8% Last Week?
text:
Why Did Gasoline Prices Fall by More Than 8% Last Week? By Keisha Bandz 8 hours ago  
( Continued from Prior Part ) Gasoline prices 
Prompt gasoline futures traded on NYMEX closed 8.41% lower on a weekly basis, at ~$1.54 per gallon, in the week ended August 21. Prices on August 14, the previous Friday, were ~$1.69 per gallon. 
Prices likely fell as a result of markets finally reacting to plunging crude oil prices. Gasoline prices were seemingly unaffected by this reaction until recently. The reason for this change was the outage at BP’s (BP) Whiting refinery, which occurred two weeks back. It created speculation that supply would tighten, boosting prices. Markets seemed to have shrugged off this speculation last week, pushing gasoline prices lower. The approach of the end of the summer driving season could also be another reason for the drop in gasoline prices. 
Prices fell despite the larger-than-expected decline in gasoline stockpiles reported by the EIA on Wednesday. You can read more about the latest gasoline inventory trends at Gasoline Inventories Are Down: Can They Support WTI? Why gasoline prices matter 
Lower gasoline prices may dissuade refiners such as Tesoro (TSO), Marathon Petroleum (MPC), and Valero Energy (VLO) from producing more gasoline. But the price of crude oil is also a consideration when refiners determine their production levels. 
Gasoline prices loosely track changes in crude oil prices (USO), usually Brent crude oil prices—the international benchmark. 
TSO, VLO, and MPC combined make up ~8.6% of the Energy Select Sector SPDRF ETF (XLE). 
So when gasoline prices fall, refiners could choose to decrease production—provided that all else, mainly crude oil prices, remains unchanged. Lower production levels would mean lower volumes for MLPs such as Tesoro Logistics (TLLP), MPLX LP (MPLX), and Valero Energy Partners (VLP) to transport. This would be negative for their revenues. Gasoline price forecasts 
According to the EIA’s “Short-Term Energy Outlook” released on August 11, monthly average gasoline retail prices reached $2.79 per gallon in July—$0.01 less than the June average. You should note that retail prices differ from the futures prices we mentioned above. They include the added cost of taxes, distribution, and marketing costs et cetera. 
Meanwhile, the EIA expects the monthly average to decline throughout the remainder of the year. The summer driving season will end in September, which should push prices lower. Gasoline prices are forecast to average $2.41 per gallon in 2015 and $2.40 per gallon in 2016. Prices averaged $3.36 per gallon in 2014. The 2016 price forecast is lower than in 2015. The EIA forecasts gasoline consumption will remain flat compared to 2015 consumption figures, offsetting the impact of economic growth. 
The EIA will release its next STEO on September 9.
